channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Greece Makes Payment to European Central Bank, Avoiding Default
item.description: Money from other eurozone countries arrived just in time for the country to repay €3.2 billion that was due on government bonds held by the central bank.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING

item.title: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras to Call New Elections, Officials Say
item.description: Mr. Tsipras, facing a revolt in his party over a bailout package, is expected to ask for new elections to be held on Sept. 20.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY and NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras answered questions in Parliament last month.

item.title: Oh, the Stories He Could Tell
item.description: Emilio Cordova, with the information he shares in his many books and newspaper columns, is a living, breathing archive of Dominican baseball.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN BLITZER
item.media:credit: Tatiana Fern?ndez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emilio Cordova, 85, known as Cuqui, working in his home office.

item.title: Palestinian Ends Fast After Israel Suspended His Detention
item.description: A Palestinian prisoner held without charge in Israel ended his two-month-long hunger strike on Thursday, his lawyer said, a day after Israel's Supreme Court suspended his detention.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Rio de Janeiro Journal: Trump Hotel Goes Up in Rio, but His Views Barely Raise Eyebrows in Brazil
item.description: The relative paucity of tension around Donald J. Trump’s lavish new venture may reflect how the country is changing — and how it is not.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Marizilda Cruppe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paulo Figueiredo Filho, a Brazilian real estate mogul and self-described conservative libertarian, at the building site of the new Trump Hotel in Rio de Janeiro.

item.title: Macedonia Detains Migrants From Greece at Border
item.description: Macedonia stepped up security on its border with Greece, blocking thousands of migrants from entering and leaving them stranded on a dusty field.

item.title: Open Source: Lebanese Police Beat ‘You Stink’ Activists in Beirut
item.description: Protesters in Lebanon call their government’s failure to arrange for trash collection just the most obvious sign of a dysfunctional administration.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Cyanide Levels Near Tianjin Blast Site Are Said to Dwarf Standard
item.description: The discovery in the northern Chinese port city raised fears that the environmental damage caused by the explosions may worsen.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.media:description: Workers near the site of the blasts in Tianjin, China, that killed more than 100 people on Aug. 12. Tests show that cyanide levels are 356 times the national standard in some areas.

item.title: Well: Researchers Link Longer Work Hours and Stroke Risk
item.description: An analysis of data on more than 600,000 people is the largest study thus far of the relationship between working hours and cardiovascular health.
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE SAINT LOUIS

item.title: ISIS Affiliate Claims Responsibility for Cairo Bombing
item.description: At least 20 people were wounded in an attack on a branch of the Egyptian security agency, adding to a wave of militant violence in the capital over the summer.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Police officers stood guard near the site of a car bomb attack in Cairo early Thursday.

item.title: North and South Korea Trade Fire Across Border, Seoul Says
item.description: No casualties were immediately reported in the exchange, the first armed clash between the rivals in five years.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: A man locking his shop after an evacuation order was issued to residents and visitors at the Imjingak Pavilion near the border village of Panmunjom in South Korea on Thursday.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Israel’s Other Existential Threat Comes From Within
item.description: The deputy speaker of the Israeli Knesset argues that failure to reach a deal with the Palestinians may be as dangerous to the Jewish state as a nuclear Iran.
item.dc:creator: HILIK BAR

item.title: Hello, Pyongyang: Are. You. Ready. To. Rock.
item.description: Laibach, a rock band from Slovenia, gave what was billed as the first live performance by a Western pop act in North Korea.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The band played at the Ponghwa Art Theater in Pyongyang on Wednesday to a capacity crowd of more than 1,000 people. In video clips from the concert, the audience watches passively and applauds politely between songs.

item.title: The Islamic State Is Forcing Women to Be Sex Slaves
item.description: The Islamic State’s leaders publicize their enslavement of women and girls in their official publication, offering a theological argument - disputed by some scholars - for why the rape of infidels is allowed.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A 12-year-old girl in the Kurdistan region of northern Iraq.

item.title: Feature: Baseball’s Last Cuban Escapees
item.description: The next generation of the country’s athlete-émigrés most likely will be ordinary rookies instead of runaways. But these major-league players got here the hard way.
item.dc:creator: SAM ANDERSON and PHOTOGRAPHS BY STEPHEN WILKES
item.media:credit: Stephen Wilkes for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left to right: Alex Guerrero, defected in 2013; Kendrys Morales, defected in 2004; Yasmani Grandal, emigrated in 1999; Odrisamer Despaigne, defected in 2013; Yasiel Puig, defected in 2012; Yonder Alonso, emigrated in 1997.

item.title: Thailand Says Bombing ‘Unlikely’ to Be Tied to International Terrorism
item.description: The motive for the attack, which struck Bangkok’s main shopping area this week, remained unknown.
item.dc:creator: POYPITI AMATATHAM
item.media:description: Visitors at the reopened Erawan Shrine in Bangkok on Thursday. Lotuses, orchids and other flowers had been left on a fence at the shrine compound in memory of those killed.

item.title: Thailand Says Bombing ‘Unlikely’ to Be Tied to International Terrorism
item.description: The motive for the attack, which struck Bangkok’s main shopping area this week, remained unknown.
item.dc:creator: POYPITI AMATATHAM
item.media:description: Visitors at the reopened Erawan Shrine in Bangkok on Thursday. Lotuses, orchids and other flowers had been left on a fence at the shrine compound in memory of those killed.

item.title: Britain and France to Announce Measures to Contain Migrant Crisis in Calais
item.description: Under plans to be formally declared later on Thursday, British police and border protection forces will work with their French counterparts at a “command and control center.”
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Migrants used cellphones along a security fence near a makeshift camp in Calais, France, on Wednesday.

item.title: Migrant Smuggling Business Is Booming in Niger, Despite Crackdown
item.description: A new anti-trafficking law has done little to end the illicit migrant trade in Agadez, a departure point for as many as 2,000 Africans a week.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Thousands of African migrants pass through Agadez, Niger, on their way to Europe via the Mediterranean Sea.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Beijing Court to Hear Suit Over Texts Calling Homosexuality an Illness
item.description: A communications student in the southern city of Guangzhou said she was shocked last year to discover textbooks that continued to define homosexuality as a sickness.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO
item.media:description: Chen Qiuyan, center, and four other students protesting the textbooks outside the Guangdong Education Department in March.
